dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The buy now, pay later space is exploding like a firework show, and Afterpay's valuation alone has shot up from 1.2 billion to 18 billion dollars in just a couple years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The buy now, pay later space is exploding like a firework show, and Afterpay's valuation alone has shot up from one point two billion to eighteen billion dollars in just a couple years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Australian company Afterpay, whose entire business is staked on the scheme, has sailed from a market valuation of $1 billion in 2018 to $18 billion today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild—and now PayPal's muscling in with their Pay in 4 product, which is interesting because they're charging no interest to consumers, just a late fee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild-and now PayPal's muscling in with their Pay in four product, which is interesting because they're charging no interest to consumers, just a late fee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wont charge interest to the consumer or an additional fee to the retailer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay a fee of up to $10.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that's different from Affirm, which usually charges interest between 10 and 30 percent, but doesn't have late fees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that's different from Affirm, which usually charges interest between ten and thirty percent, but doesn't have late fees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But most of the time, it makes users pay interest of 10 - 30%, and it has no late fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And PayPal can afford to undercut everyone because they already have this massive payments network. I mean, 80% of the top U.S. retailers already use PayPal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And PayPal can afford to undercut everyone because they already have this massive payments network. I mean, eighty percent of the top U.S. retailers already use PayPal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Eighty percent of the top 100 retailers in the U.S. let customers pay with PayPal, and nearly 70% of U.S. online buyers have PayPal accounts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and during the pandemic, their revenue hit 5.3 billion in just one quarter. They're basically printing money while everyone shops online.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and during the pandemic, their revenue hit five point three billion in just one quarter. They're basically printing money while everyone shops online.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal charges retailers per-transaction fees of 2.9% plus $0.30, and in the second quarter, as Covid-19 made online purchases skyrocket, it saw record revenues of $5.3 billion and profits of $1.5 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's smart too—data shows people spend like 18% more when they're offered these installment plans, so PayPal's transaction sizes are gonna go up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's smart too-data shows people spend like eighteen percent more when they're offered these installment plans, so PayPal's transaction sizes are gonna go up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Data from Afterpay and PayPal show that consumers spend more moneysometimes 20% morewhen theyre offered point of sale financing options.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And since they take a cut of every transaction, their fee revenue rises right along with it. It's a pretty slick move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And since they take a cut of every transaction, their fee revenue rises right along with it. It's a pretty slick move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When PayPal launches Pay in 4 this fall, it will likely see transaction sizes rise, and since it already earns 2.9% on each transaction, its fee revenue will rise in tandem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, didn't they already have PayPal Credit? That's the one with high interest rates, around 25%, and they offload most of that risk to Synchrony Bank.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, didn't they already have PayPal Credit? That's the one with high interest rates, around twenty five percent, and they offload most of that risk to Synchrony Bank.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Like a credit card, it levies high interest rates of about 25% and requires monthly payments. These consumer loans can have a high risk of default, and PayPal doesnt own most of themit offloads the U.S. loans to Synchrony Bank.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but with Pay in 4, they're keeping the loans on their own balance sheet this time. They say they're comfortable managing the credit risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but with Pay in four, they're keeping the loans on their own balance sheet this time. They say they're comfortable managing the credit risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike PayPal Credit, PayPal will house these new loans on its own balance sheet. Bland says, Were incredibly comfortable in managing the credit risk of this.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even after they paused lending back in March when the pandemic hit? That was a cautious move for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even after they paused lending back in March when the pandemic hit? That was a cautious move for sure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This past spring, as the pandemic was spreading quickly and concerns spiked about consumers defaulting on loans, PayPal pumped the brakes on lending. Like many installment lenders, they essentially halted extending loans in March or early April, MoffettNathansons Ellis says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but now they're jumping back in, which tells you they think consumers are doing better than expected in this economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but now they're jumping back in, which tells you they think consumers are doing better than expected in this economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With Pay in 4, PayPals renewed push into lending is an indication the company is getting more aggressive in a volatile economy where many consumers have fared better than expected so far.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And you've got players like Klarna and Sezzle also in the mix, each with over a million users. This market is getting crowded fast.
